confusion_pairs.title: Incident vs Event

a.definition: Any observable occurrence in a system or network (a log entry, an alert, a connection).

b.definition: An event (or series of events) that violates policy, impacts security, or requires response actions.

bullets: Events are constant; incidents are the subset that matter.
An IDS alert is an event; confirmed malware execution is an incident.
Treating every event as an incident causes alert fatigue.

confusion_pairs.title: Policy vs Standard vs Procedure

a.definition: High-level, management-approved statements of intent (the 'what' and 'why').

b.definition: Standards set specific mandatory requirements; procedures give step-by-step 'how' to do the work.

bullets: Policy: 'Logs must be retained.' Standard: 'Retain auth logs 365 days.' Procedure: 'How to configure log rotation and archiving.'
Policies change slowly; procedures evolve fastest.
Audit finds missing standards/procedures even if policy exists.

confusion_pairs.title: Tabletop Exercise vs Simulation

a.definition: Discussion-based walkthrough of an incident using a scenario; validates roles, decisions, and communication.

b.definition: Hands-on or realistic drill that triggers tools/processes as if the incident is happening (often with injected artifacts).

bullets: Tabletop tests thinking and coordination; simulation tests execution under pressure.
Simulations expose tooling gaps (missing logs, bad alert tuning) faster.
Run tabletop first, then graduate to simulations.

confusion_pairs.title: Business Continuity vs Disaster Recovery

a.definition: How the business keeps operating at an acceptable level during disruption.

b.definition: How IT restores systems, data, and infrastructure after a major disruption.

bullets: BCP is business-first; DR is IT restoration-focused.
BCP may use workarounds; DR rebuilds/recovers the tech stack.
Both should align to RTO/RPO targets (time and data loss tolerances).

confusion_pairs.title: SIEM vs SOAR

a.definition: Collects/aggregates logs, correlates signals, and alerts/reporting for detection and investigation.

b.definition: Orchestrates and automates response workflows (playbooks), often consuming SIEM alerts.

bullets: SIEM helps you *see*; SOAR helps you *do*.
SOAR is only as good as the detections feeding it (garbage alerts → automated garbage).
Typical flow: sources → SIEM correlation → alert → SOAR playbook → ticket/containment.

confusion_pairs.title: Log Aggregation vs Correlation

a.definition: Centralizing and storing logs from many sources in one place.

b.definition: Linking multiple events together to identify a meaningful pattern (often across sources/time).

bullets: Aggregation is necessary but not sufficient for detection.
Correlation answers 'these events together mean something' (e.g., impossible travel + failed logins + new admin group).
Poor correlation rules = noisy alerts and missed incidents.

confusion_pairs.title: Containment vs Isolation

a.definition: Limit damage/spread while preserving evidence and business function as much as possible.

b.definition: Cut a system off from the network/resources to stop active harm, often more disruptive.

bullets: Containment can be 'surgical' (block C2 domain); isolation is 'amputate the limb'.
Isolation can destroy volatile evidence if done badly; plan it.
Use segmentation/quarantine as middle-ground containment options.

confusion_pairs.title: Allow list vs Deny list

a.definition: Only explicitly approved items are permitted; everything else is blocked by default.

b.definition: Explicitly blocked items are denied; everything else is allowed by default.

bullets: Allow lists reduce unknown risk but require maintenance and change control.
Deny lists are easier to start with but are always behind (new bad stuff appears).
For high-risk environments, prefer allow listing.

confusion_pairs.title: NetFlow vs sFlow

a.definition: Flow records about conversations (5‑tuple, bytes, time) exported from network devices.

b.definition: Sampling-based traffic monitoring exporting selected packet/flow samples instead of every flow.

bullets: NetFlow/IPFIX gives richer per-flow records; sFlow trades detail for scalability via sampling.
Sampling can miss short-lived events; tune sampling rates to your risk tolerance.
Both help you see 'who talked to whom' even when payloads are encrypted.

confusion_pairs.title: Kill Chain vs MITRE ATT&CK

a.definition: A staged model of an attack from recon through actions on objectives; used to find breakpoints.

b.definition: A detailed matrix of adversary tactics/techniques used to map detections, threats, and controls.

bullets: Kill chain is a high-level narrative; ATT&CK is a granular catalog.
Use kill chain for strategy; use ATT&CK for detection engineering and coverage gaps.
Both help prioritize controls that disrupt common attacker behaviors.

attack_frameworks.diamond_model.rule: Use the Diamond Model to describe an intrusion using four nodes: adversary, infrastructure, capability, victim.
attack_frameworks.diamond_model.micro_example: Example: Adversary uses phishing (capability) from VPS IPs (infrastructure) against HR (victim).

attack_frameworks.kill_chain.rule: Treat attacks as stages; disrupt the chain early to reduce impact.
attack_frameworks.kill_chain.micro_example: Example: Block delivery (email filtering) or stop exploitation (patching) before C2 happens.

attack_frameworks.mitre_attack.rule: Map detections and mitigations to ATT&CK tactics/techniques to find coverage gaps.
attack_frameworks.mitre_attack.micro_example: Example: Detect 'Valid Accounts' by alerting on impossible travel + new admin group adds.

benchmarks.logging_baselines.rule: Baseline normal behavior first; alerts should fire on meaningful deviation, not on 'everything'.
benchmarks.logging_baselines.micro_example: Example: CPU at 90% is normal on backup night—alert only when it happens out of cycle.

incident_response.basics.incident_vs_eve.rule: An incident is an event that matters enough to require response; don’t panic at every log line.
incident_response.basics.incident_vs_eve.micro_example: Example: 1 failed login = event; 500 failed logins + successful admin login = incident.

incident_response.cycle.analysis.rule: Analysis is separating 'noise' from 'attack' and scoping what’s affected.
incident_response.cycle.analysis.micro_example: Example: Confirm if the alert is a false positive; identify impacted hosts and accounts.

incident_response.cycle.containment.rule: Containment limits damage and spread while keeping evidence and operations in mind.
incident_response.cycle.containment.micro_example: Example: Block C2 domains and quarantine endpoints instead of nuking everything.

incident_response.cycle.detection.rule: Detection is spotting the signal: alerts, anomalies, and indicators that something is wrong.
incident_response.cycle.detection.micro_example: Example: SIEM flags impossible travel + concurrent sessions for a privileged user.

incident_response.cycle.eradication.rule: Eradication removes the root cause (malware, accounts, persistence) after you understand scope.
incident_response.cycle.eradication.micro_example: Example: Remove persistence, reset creds, patch the exploited service, and kill backdoors.

incident_response.cycle.lessons_learned.rule: Lessons learned turns pain into process: document, fix gaps, tune alerts, update playbooks.
incident_response.cycle.lessons_learned.micro_example: Example: Add missing logs, adjust thresholds, and update the contact/approval chain.

incident_response.cycle.preparation.rule: Preparation is where you win: playbooks, tools, access, logging, and training before the incident.
incident_response.cycle.preparation.micro_example: Example: Pre-stage IR kits, contacts, and an isolation procedure so you’re not improvising.

incident_response.cycle.recovery.rule: Recovery safely returns systems to production with monitoring for re‑infection.
incident_response.cycle.recovery.micro_example: Example: Restore from clean backups, re-enable services gradually, and watch for beaconing.

incident_response.exercises.simulation.rule: Simulations test execution: tools, logging, and muscle memory under realistic conditions.
incident_response.exercises.simulation.micro_example: Example: Inject a fake C2 beacon and verify the team can detect, isolate, and ticket it.

incident_response.exercises.tabletop.rule: Tabletops test decisions and communication without touching production systems.
incident_response.exercises.tabletop.micro_example: Example: Walk through ransomware response: who approves isolation, who talks to customers?

incident_response.plans.business_continu.rule: BCP is about keeping the business running during disruption—even with workarounds.
incident_response.plans.business_continu.micro_example: Example: Manual order-taking while the e-commerce platform is down.

incident_response.plans.communication.rule: Communications plans prevent chaos: define who says what, to whom, and when.
incident_response.plans.communication.micro_example: Example: Internal update cadence + external statement templates + legal review path.

incident_response.plans.disaster_recover.rule: DR is about restoring IT services and data after a major outage or destructive incident.
incident_response.plans.disaster_recover.micro_example: Example: Rebuild from IaC, restore backups, validate integrity, then cut traffic back.

incident_response.plans.stakeholder_mana.rule: Stakeholders need accurate, timely updates; manage expectations and approvals explicitly.
incident_response.plans.stakeholder_mana.micro_example: Example: Execs get impact + options; IT gets tasks; legal/comms gets messaging control.

incident_response.policy.policy_vs_stand.rule: Policy is the 'what/why'; standards and procedures are the enforceable 'how'.
incident_response.policy.policy_vs_stand.micro_example: Example: Policy says 'retain logs'; a standard sets retention days; procedure configures it.

incident_response.policy.purpose.rule: IR policy exists to set authority, scope, and expectations for responding to incidents.
incident_response.policy.purpose.micro_example: Example: Policy defines when to involve legal, when to preserve evidence, and who leads.

incident_response.team.comms_pr.rule: Comms/PR manages external messaging to customers, media, and partners.
incident_response.team.comms_pr.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.team.hr.rule: HR handles employee-related incidents, policy violations, and insider procedures.
incident_response.team.hr.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.team.infosec.rule: Infosec leads technical security investigation and coordination.
incident_response.team.infosec.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.team.law_enforcement.rule: Law enforcement engagement is for criminal cases; coordinate via legal.
incident_response.team.law_enforcement.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.team.legal.rule: Legal guides liability, evidence handling, and disclosure requirements.
incident_response.team.legal.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.team.management_lead.rule: Management lead provides authority, prioritization, and resource decisions.
incident_response.team.management_lead.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.team.technical_experts.rule: Technical SMEs (network/app/cloud) execute deep fixes and forensics.
incident_response.team.technical_experts.micro_example: Example: Legal approves external disclosures; infosec directs containment; IT restores systems.

incident_response.training.programs.rule: Train regularly so response is a practiced routine, not a panic improvisation.
incident_response.training.programs.micro_example: Example: Quarterly drills + annual refresh of tooling and contact lists.

investigation.automated_reports_dashboar.rule: Dashboards speed triage, but always drill down to raw evidence before declaring victory.
investigation.automated_reports_dashboar.micro_example: Example: A chart shows spikes; pivot to the underlying events and affected assets.

investigation.metadata.email.rule: Email metadata helps trace sender, route, and spoofing patterns.
investigation.metadata.email.micro_example: Example: Compare 'Received:' hops, SPF/DKIM results, and sending IP reputation.

investigation.metadata.file_exif.rule: EXIF/file metadata can reveal origin, timestamps, device info, and tampering clues.
investigation.metadata.file_exif.micro_example: Example: Photo EXIF shows GPS coords or camera model; file times mismatch may indicate staging.

investigation.metadata.mobile.rule: Mobile metadata includes app events, location signals, and device state useful for IR.
investigation.metadata.mobile.micro_example: Example: App install timestamps + MDM compliance logs + last known location.

investigation.metadata.web.rule: Web metadata (headers, logs) helps reconstruct sessions and identify malicious requests.
investigation.metadata.web.micro_example: Example: User-agent anomalies + referrers + suspicious POSTs in access logs.

investigation.packet_capture.rule: Packet capture is the ground truth for network behavior—use it when logs aren’t enough.
investigation.packet_capture.micro_example: Example: Confirm beaconing to a C2 IP even if the endpoint logs are missing.

investigation.vulnerability_scans.rule: Vulnerability scans reveal exposed weaknesses; use them to confirm likely entry points.
investigation.vulnerability_scans.micro_example: Example: Scan shows unpatched VPN appliance CVE that matches attacker technique.

logging.linux.journald_journalctl.rule: On systemd Linux, journald stores logs; journalctl is how you query them.
logging.linux.journald_journalctl.micro_example: Example: 'journalctl -u sshd --since today' to review SSH auth events.

logging.protocols.nxlog.rule: NXLog is a flexible log forwarder/collector that can translate formats and ship to SIEMs.
logging.protocols.nxlog.micro_example: Example: Convert Windows Event Log to syslog/JSON and forward securely.

logging.protocols.rsyslog.rule: rsyslog is a common Linux syslog daemon for receiving/forwarding and filtering logs.
logging.protocols.rsyslog.micro_example: Example: Use rsyslog rules to forward auth.log and firewall logs to the SIEM.

logging.protocols.syslog.rule: Syslog is the standard log transport format for many network/security devices.
logging.protocols.syslog.micro_example: Example: Firewalls send syslog to a central collector/SIEM.

logging.protocols.syslog_ng.rule: syslog-ng is an enhanced syslog daemon with richer filtering/parsing options.
logging.protocols.syslog_ng.micro_example: Example: Parse JSON logs and route by facility/severity to different destinations.

logging.retention.lifecycle.rule: Retention is a lifecycle: collect → store → rotate → archive → dispose, aligned to policy and law.
logging.retention.lifecycle.micro_example: Example: Keep hot logs 30 days, archive 365 days, then destroy securely.

logging.sources.application.rule: Application logs show app errors, auth events, and business actions.
logging.sources.application.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.sources.endpoint.rule: Endpoint logs show process execution, installs, and security agent events.
logging.sources.endpoint.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.sources.firewall.rule: Firewall logs show allowed/blocked connections and policy hits.
logging.sources.firewall.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.sources.ids_ips.rule: IDS/IPS logs show detections, signatures, and blocked/alerted traffic.
logging.sources.ids_ips.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.sources.linux_auth_logs.rule: Linux auth logs track sudo/ssh logins and authentication events.
logging.sources.linux_auth_logs.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.sources.network.rule: Network device logs show routing/switching events and anomalies.
logging.sources.network.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.sources.windows_security_log.rule: Windows Security Log tracks auth, privilege use, and auditing events.
logging.sources.windows_security_log.micro_example: Example: Combine firewall + endpoint + auth logs to validate a suspected compromise.

logging.tools.event_viewer.rule: Event Viewer is the native tool to review Windows Event Logs; know where Security events live.
logging.tools.event_viewer.micro_example: Example: Filter Security log for failed logons (4625) and privilege use.

logging.tools.grep_tail.rule: grep/tail are fast triage tools for text logs—use them to slice big files quickly.
logging.tools.grep_tail.micro_example: Example: 'tail -f /var/log/auth.log | grep sshd' during an active incident.

mitigation.allow_list.rule: Allow listing is default-deny: only known-good apps/paths are allowed to run.
mitigation.allow_list.micro_example: Example: Only signed corporate apps run; unknown binaries are blocked.

mitigation.cert_update_revoke.rule: Update/revoke certificates when keys may be compromised; trust can’t be assumed.
mitigation.cert_update_revoke.micro_example: Example: Revoke a stolen device cert and push a new one via PKI/MDM.

mitigation.configuration_changes.rule: Configuration changes can eradicate persistence and close exploited paths—track and approve them.
mitigation.configuration_changes.micro_example: Example: Disable vulnerable service, rotate keys, and enforce MFA on admin accounts.

mitigation.containment_vs_isolation.rule: Containment limits spread; isolation is the hard cutoff—pick the least disruptive option that stops harm.
mitigation.containment_vs_isolation.micro_example: Example: Block C2 (containment) vs unplug host from network (isolation).

mitigation.content_url_filtering.rule: Content/URL filtering blocks known-bad categories/domains and reduces drive-by risk.
mitigation.content_url_filtering.micro_example: Example: Block newly-registered domains and malware hosting categories.

mitigation.deny_list.rule: Deny listing blocks known-bad items, but new/renamed malware slips through.
mitigation.deny_list.micro_example: Example: Blocking hash X helps today; attacker recompiles and bypasses tomorrow.

mitigation.dlp_changes.rule: DLP changes reduce data exfil during/after an incident by tightening controls and rules.
mitigation.dlp_changes.micro_example: Example: Block uploads to personal cloud storage for high-risk groups temporarily.

mitigation.firewall_rules.rule: Firewall rule changes are fast containment—block IOCs, restrict ports, and tighten egress.
mitigation.firewall_rules.micro_example: Example: Block outbound to C2 IPs/domains and limit SMB east-west.

mitigation.isolation.rule: Isolation cuts a system off to stop harm fast—plan it to avoid losing evidence.
mitigation.isolation.micro_example: Example: EDR network isolate a host, then collect memory/disk before reimaging.

mitigation.mdm_actions.rule: MDM actions enforce mobile security: lock, wipe, remove apps, force updates, or restrict features.
mitigation.mdm_actions.micro_example: Example: Selective wipe corporate container after a BYOD employee leaves.

mitigation.monitoring_validation.rule: After containment/eradication, validate with monitoring that the threat didn’t come back.
mitigation.monitoring_validation.micro_example: Example: Watch for repeated beaconing or re-created scheduled tasks over 72 hours.

mitigation.quarantine.rule: Quarantine is a containment middle-ground: restrict access while keeping minimal connectivity for remediation.
mitigation.quarantine.micro_example: Example: Put a host in a remediation VLAN that only reaches patch/AV servers.

mitigation.segmentation.rule: Segmentation reduces blast radius by limiting lateral movement with network boundaries.
mitigation.segmentation.micro_example: Example: Separate user VLANs from server VLANs; require firewall rules between them.

monitoring.resources.applications.rule: Monitor application behavior and logs (errors, auth, transactions, API abuse).
monitoring.resources.applications.micro_example: Example: Spike in 500 errors + unusual POSTs may indicate exploitation.

monitoring.resources.infrastructure.rule: Monitor infrastructure components (network devices, hypervisors, storage, identity services).
monitoring.resources.infrastructure.micro_example: Example: Firewall rule changes or VPN auth failures can be early warning signals.

monitoring.resources.systems.rule: Monitor systems health and security signals (CPU, disk, auth, processes).
monitoring.resources.systems.micro_example: Example: Sudden CPU spikes + new scheduled tasks can indicate compromise.

network_flows.ipfix.rule: IPFIX is the IETF standard flow export format (NetFlow-like, extensible).
network_flows.ipfix.micro_example: Example: Export IPFIX from routers to your collector for long-term traffic baselining.

network_flows.netflow.rule: NetFlow summarizes traffic as flows (who/what/when/how much) without full payloads.
network_flows.netflow.micro_example: Example: Detect a workstation sending 10GB to an unknown ASN overnight.

network_flows.sampling_limitations.rule: Sampling trades accuracy for performance; tune rates so you don’t miss short-lived attacks.
network_flows.sampling_limitations.micro_example: Example: A brief beacon every 5 minutes may vanish in aggressive sampling.

network_flows.sflow.rule: sFlow uses sampling to scale traffic visibility—great at high speeds, less detailed for short events.
network_flows.sflow.micro_example: Example: Use sFlow on core switches where full NetFlow export is too heavy.

rca.event_analysis.rule: Event analysis reconstructs timelines to understand what happened and what triggered it.
rca.event_analysis.micro_example: Example: Sequence: phishing email → login → privilege escalation → exfil attempt.

rca.fishbone_diagram.rule: Fishbone (Ishikawa) diagrams categorize causes (people, process, tech, environment) to find roots.
rca.fishbone_diagram.micro_example: Example: Incident causes grouped into training gaps, tooling gaps, and policy gaps.

rca.five_whys.rule: Five Whys drills down from symptom to root cause by repeatedly asking 'why?'.
rca.five_whys.micro_example: Example: Outage → why? Disk full → why? Logs not rotated → why? No retention standard.

siem.basics.alerting.rule: Alerting notifies responders of high-signal events; quality beats quantity.
siem.basics.alerting.micro_example: Example: Page only when confidence or business impact is high.

siem.basics.archiving.rule: Archiving preserves logs for investigations, compliance, and long-tail threats.
siem.basics.archiving.micro_example: Example: Move old logs to cheaper storage while keeping them searchable.

siem.basics.correlation.rule: Correlation links multiple events into a higher-confidence detection.
siem.basics.correlation.micro_example: Example: Impossible travel + MFA push fatigue + new admin group add = high severity.

siem.basics.definition.rule: A SIEM centralizes logs and security signals for correlation, alerting, and investigation.
siem.basics.definition.micro_example: Example: Ingest firewall + endpoint + auth logs, then alert on suspicious patterns.

siem.basics.log_aggregation.rule: Aggregation is centralized log collection—do it before you try to detect anything fancy.
siem.basics.log_aggregation.micro_example: Example: Forward syslog + Windows events into one searchable index.

siem.basics.packet_capture_input.rule: Some SIEMs ingest packet/flow data as context; it complements logs when endpoints lie or go dark.
siem.basics.packet_capture_input.micro_example: Example: Flow shows outbound beacons even when host logs are wiped.

siem.basics.reporting.rule: Reporting turns raw events into metrics and stories for stakeholders.
siem.basics.reporting.micro_example: Example: Weekly top alerts, mean time to respond, and trending attack techniques.

siem.dashboard.alert_tuning.rule: Alert tuning cuts noise: adjust rules, thresholds, and suppressions until alerts are actionable.
siem.dashboard.alert_tuning.micro_example: Example: Suppress known scanner IPs; tighten thresholds; add allow list exceptions.

siem.dashboard.sensors.rule: Sensors are your inputs; missing coverage equals blind spots.
siem.dashboard.sensors.micro_example: Example: No DNS logs? You’ll miss lots of phishing/malware resolution signals.

siem.dashboard.thresholds_sensitivity.rule: Sensitivity is a trade: higher sensitivity finds more but creates more false positives.
siem.dashboard.thresholds_sensitivity.micro_example: Example: Lower brute-force threshold catches attacks early but pages you for user typos.

siem.dashboard.trends.rule: Trends show whether your situation is improving or drifting into chaos.
siem.dashboard.trends.micro_example: Example: Rising impossible-travel alerts after a VPN rollout signals policy mismatch or abuse.

siem.integration.cloud_saas.rule: Cloud/SaaS integrations extend SIEM visibility beyond on-prem (IdP, email, IaaS audit logs).
siem.integration.cloud_saas.micro_example: Example: Ingest Azure AD sign-in logs + O365 audit events + cloud firewall logs.

siem.terms.sim_sem.rule: SIM = log collection/management; SEM = real-time security monitoring—modern SIEMs blend both.
siem.terms.sim_sem.micro_example: Example: Store logs for months (SIM) and alert on anomalies today (SEM).

soar.platforms.rule: SOAR automates response playbooks—use it to speed containment while keeping approvals sane.
soar.platforms.micro_example: Example: Auto-create ticket, enrich with WHOIS, and quarantine endpoint after analyst approval.

threat_hunting.ioc.account_lockout.rule: Account lockouts can signal brute force, password spraying, or misconfigured automation.
threat_hunting.ioc.account_lockout.micro_example: Example: Multiple lockouts across many users from one IP = password spray clue.

threat_hunting.ioc.blocked_content.rule: Blocked content events can reveal malware/phishing attempts that were stopped—or repeated probing.
threat_hunting.ioc.blocked_content.micro_example: Example: Web filter blocks downloads of 'invoice.exe' repeatedly from one host.

threat_hunting.ioc.concurrent_sessions.rule: Concurrent sessions for one account may indicate credential theft or shared accounts.
threat_hunting.ioc.concurrent_sessions.micro_example: Example: Same user logged in from VPN and overseas IP at the same time.

threat_hunting.ioc.impossible_travel.rule: Impossible travel is a strong identity anomaly: the same account appears in far locations too quickly.
threat_hunting.ioc.impossible_travel.micro_example: Example: Sign-in from Dhaka then Frankfurt 10 minutes later = investigate.

threat_hunting.ioc.missing_logs.rule: Missing logs can be a detection itself: attackers delete logs or disable forwarders.
threat_hunting.ioc.missing_logs.micro_example: Example: Endpoint stops sending logs right before a suspicious admin login.

threat_hunting.ioc.out_of_cycle_logging.rule: Out-of-cycle logging (events at odd times) can signal scheduled tasks, persistence, or abuse.
threat_hunting.ioc.out_of_cycle_logging.micro_example: Example: Admin actions at 3:17 AM when the team is asleep.

threat_hunting.ioc.published_documented.rule: Published/documented indicators are known IOCs/techniques from intel feeds—use them, but verify.
threat_hunting.ioc.published_documented.micro_example: Example: Feed flags domain X; confirm your logs show connections before blocking broadly.

threat_hunting.ioc.resource_consumption.rule: Unexpected CPU/disk/network spikes can indicate crypto-mining, exfiltration, or malware activity.
threat_hunting.ioc.resource_consumption.micro_example: Example: Endpoint uploads gigabytes overnight while CPU pegs at 95%.

threat_hunting.ioc.resource_inaccessibil.rule: Sudden resource inaccessibility can indicate ransomware, DoS, or account permission abuse.
threat_hunting.ioc.resource_inaccessibil.micro_example: Example: Many files become unreadable and extensions change = ransomware suspicion.
